content: The Act titled "Hurricane and Tornado Mitigation Investment Act of 2007" introduces a nonrefundable personal credit for hurricane and tornado mitigation property under section 25E of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Act "Hurricane and Tornado Mitigation Investment Act of 2007" introduces a nonrefundable personal credit for qualified hurricane and tornado mitigation property expenditures. The credit is 25% of the expenditures, not exceeding $5,000 per year, for improving roof deck attachment, creating a secondary water barrier, and enhancing roof covering durability. The Act "Hurricane and Tornado Mitigation Investment Act of 2007" offers a nonrefundable personal credit for qualified hurricane and tornado mitigation property expenditures. This includes improving roof deck attachment, creating a secondary water barrier, enhancing roof covering durability, bracing gable-end walls, reinforcing roof-to-wall connections, protecting openings from windborne debris, and safeguarding exterior doors and garages in qualified dwelling units located in specific states. A qualified dwelling unit is assessed at a value less than $1,000,000 in the locality where it is situated. The Act "Hurricane and Tornado Mitigation Investment Act of 2007" provides a nonrefundable personal credit for qualified hurricane and tornado mitigation property expenditures. Expenditures must be made in specific states and onsite preparation must be deemed adequate by a State-certified inspector. Labor costs allocated to onsite preparation are also eligible for the credit. The Act allows for labor costs and inspection costs related to onsite preparation, assembly, or installation of qualified hurricane and tornado mitigation property to be considered in determining eligible expenditures for the taxpayer. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007. A new section, SEC. 45O, provides a business-related credit for hurricane and tornado mitigation. The hurricane and tornado mitigation credit allows for a 25% credit on qualified property expenditures, with a maximum credit of $5,000 per year. Qualified expenditures include improving roof deck attachment, creating a secondary water barrier, and enhancing roof covering durability. The hurricane and tornado mitigation credit offers a 25% credit on qualified property expenditures, with a maximum of $5,000 per year. Qualified expenditures include improving roof deck attachment, creating a secondary water barrier, enhancing roof covering durability, bracing gable-end walls, reinforcing roof-to-wall connections, protecting openings from windborne debris, and safeguarding exterior doors and garages in eligible businesses in states with assessed property values under $5,000,000. The term 'qualified State' includes specific states where the taxpayer must complete onsite preparation, assembly, or installation of qualified hurricane and tornado mitigation property to be eligible for the tax credit. Labor costs are also considered as part of qualified expenditures. Labor costs and inspection costs related to the onsite preparation, assembly, or installation of qualified hurricane and tornado mitigation property are considered in determining the taxpayer's qualified expenditures for the tax credit. The tax credit for hurricane and tornado mitigation property is amended by adding a new paragraph and a new item in the table of sections. The tax credit for hurricane and tornado mitigation property is amended to include a new section, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2007.
